Rav Eliezer Yehudah Waldenberg

Rav Eliezer Yehudah (ben Yaakov Gedalyahu) Waldenberg (1914- 2006). Born in Yerushalayim, his father came to Eretz Yisrael from Kovno in the early 1900s. He learned in the Eitz Chaim Yeshiva under Rav Isser Zalman Meltzer. Rav Waldenberg wrote his first sefer, Dvar Eliezer, when he was only 19. Upon the passing of his mother and later his father both in the 1960s, he published Ein Ya'acov on the halachos of mourning. Rav Waldenberg got involved with medical ethics during the period that he served as rabbi of a shul adjacent to the old location of Sha'arei Tzedek Hospital in downtown Yerushalayim. His teshuvos were compiled in his magnum opus, a 22-volume set of responsa entitled Tzitz Eliezer. He also authored a book on the laws of sea travel on Shabbos called Shvisa b'Yam and a book on legal issues in the modern state called Hilchos Medina. He wrote two books on mourning, Even Yaakov for his father and Ramat Rachel for his mother. He was also a member on the Beis Din Hagadol. He and his Rebbetzin merited to have one child, a son, Rav Simcha Bunim Waldenberg. Rav Simcha Bunim became a dayan in the Eidah Hachareidis and served as its appointed Rov of the neighborhood of Ezras Torah. He himself was known as a posek muvhak. Tragically, Rav Simcha Bunim passed away at an early age.

Rav Asher Fasman

Rav Asher (Oscar) Fasman (1908-2003). Born in Chicago, he served as Rav in Tulsa, Oklahoma, and Ottowa, Canada, before returning to Chicago. He developed Hebrew Theological College from an afternoon only school to a full-time yeshiva, bringing gedolei Torah as Roshei Yeshiva. He was president of the yeshiva from 1946 to 1964, and also served as president of the Chicago Rabbinical Council and rav of Congregation Yehuda Moshe in Lincolnwood, Illinois. His son, Rav Chaim Fasman, is Rosh Kollel in Los Angeles.

Rav Tzvi Hersh Hakohen

Rav Tzvi Hersh Hakohen of Rimanov (1778-1846). From the age of fifteen, Tzvi Hersh began traveling to the court of Rav Menachem Mendel of Rimanov. He became one of the Rebbe’s closest chassisdim and his personal attendant; he thus became know as Rav Tzvi Hersh Meshares. Rabbeinu Yonah

Rabbeinu Yonah (ben Avraham) of Gerona, Spain (1200 [1180]-1263). The Ramban's mother and Rabbeinu Yonah’s father were siblings. Many years later, the Ramban’s son, Rav Shlomo, married  the daughter of Rabbeinu Yonah. Thus, the two great rishonim were mechutanim as well as first cousins. He was a student of Rav Shlomo ben Avraham Min Ha'Har. When King Louis XIV of France burnt all the copies of the Talmud in Paris in the Square of the Louvre, Rabbeinu Yonah, one of the Rambam’s main detractors, felt that the events in Paris were a sign that he and the other opponents of the Rambam were seriously wrong. He then composed his work Shaarei Teshuvah, in which he outlined the methods of doing Teshuvah, and he traveled from place to place preaching about the need to back away from matters which cause division among the Jewish People. Among his talmidim are the Rashba and Ra’ah. [Others cite his yahrtzeit as 1, 8, or 11 Cheshvan]

Rav Yaakov Eliezer

Rav Yaakov Eliezer (ben Dovid Yitzchak), the Pshevorsker Rebbe, also known as RebYankele of Antwerp (1907-1999 [1998, per Hamodia 2010]). Born in the small village of Roig near Riminov in Galicia, he learned at Yeshivas Zera Kodesh in Koloshitz. Staying there from 1924 to 1939, Reb Yankele regarded the Koloshitzer Rav as his Rebbe and mentor. His first position was as Rav of Yashlisk, at the age of 24. After his marriage to the daughter of Reb Itzikel, the Rebbe of Pshevorsk in 1934, he lived in the shadow of his shver for the next forty years. When the Germans arrived in Pshevorsk, Reb Itzikel and Reb Yankele fled to Lemberg, which was under the control of Russia. On the 23rd of Sivan 1940, both were sent to Siberia. The Germans entered Lemberg a short while later and brutally murdered almost the whole Jewish population. Those who had been exiled to Siberia were the lucky ones. After the war's end, Reb Yankele took up the position of dayan in Breslau, and then moved to Paris, and then Antwerp. With Reb Itzikel's petirah on Yom Kippur 1976, Reb Yankele was chosen as his shver's successor.

Rav Shmuel Halevi Ashlag

Rav Shmuel Halevi Ashlag (1996)

Rav Yitzchak Shmuel Eliyahu Finkler

Rav Yitzchak Shmuel Eliyahu (ben Meir Menachem) Finkler (1892-1944). Son of the fifth Radoshitz  (Radowchitz) Rebbe, he married the daughter of the Kozhmirer Rebbe, replacing him upon his petira in 1912. He and his family were taken to the Skarzysko concentration camp in February of 1943. His daughter Malka survived the war, moved to Eretz Yisrael, and married Yechiel Granatstein. Among his son-in-law’s books is the biographical “One Jew's Power One Jew's Glory: The Life of Rav Yitzchak Shumuel Eliyahu Finkler the Rebbe of Radoschitz in the Ghetto and Concentration Camps,” published by Feldheim in 1991.

Rav Dovid Friedman

Rav Dovid (ben Shalom Yosef) Friedman, Rebbe of Ployesht (1898-1940). Born in Shpikov, he was a descendent of the Ruzhiner Rebbe. After marrying, he moved to Romania in 1930 and opened his beis midrash in Ployesht. The Rebbe was imprisoned by the National Legionary State in early Cheshvan of 1940, under the claim that he was a Soviet spy. In 1969, his remains were brought to Eretz Yisroel and buried in the Nachlas Yitzchak cemetery in Tel Aviv. Although he wrote many manuscripts and divrei Torah, they were all lost during the War.

Rav Moshe Mordechai

Rav Moshe Mordechai of Pelzovizna (1916)

Rav Meir Binyamin Menachim Dunin

Rav Meir Binyamin Menachim Dunin, author of Be’er Hasadeh (1848)

Rav Shmuel Hayashish

Rav Shmuel Hayashish, Rav of London (1842)

Rav Rafael Ashkenazi

Rav Rafael Ashkenazi of Izmir, author of Mareh Einayim (1825)

Rav Dovid

Rav Dovid (ben Aryeh Leib), Rav of Lida, Magentza, and Amsterdam (~1650-1696). He was the author of many sefarim including Ir Dovid, Ir Miklat (a commentary on the 613 mitzvos), Sod Hashem (on bris mila) and Sharvit Hazahav (a commentary on Sod Hashem), Divre Dovid (a book on morals), Sefer Helke Abanim (a commentary on Rashi on chumash), Migdal Dovid (a kabalistic commentary on Rus),. In 1682 he went to Amsterdam, and became rabbi of the Ashkenazic community there. He died in Lemberg, Poland.

Rav Yaakov ibn Chaviv

Rav Yaakov ibn Chaviv (Yaakov ben Shlomo Chaviv), author of Ein Yaakov (1509) [1516, While he resided in Spain Rav Yaakov had planned to write a compendium of the Aggada portion of the Talmud but was unable to do so due to the very limited availability of the Talmud and meforshim in Christian Spain.  After the expulsion in 1492 he moved to Portugal and finally settled in Salonika where he found copies of the entire Talmud as well as the commentaries of Ramban, Rashba, Ritva, Ran and Baalei Tosfot.  In his old age Rav Yaakov began compiling his work and published seder Zeraim and seder Moed prior to his death. His son, Rav Levi was forcibly baptized while they were in Portugal, but later became an illustrious talmudist known as the Ralbach and later moved to Eretz Yisrael to atone for his baptism, becoming Rav of Yerushalayim.  It was Rav Levi who completed the other 4 sedarim, but with little commentary.

Rav Mordechai Zimmerman

Rav Mordechai (ben Yosef Yehoshua) Zimmerman, renown mohel (1913-2005). Born in New York, he attended Torah Vodaas, which his father help found. He and his two brothers were sent to Mir and Grodna in Europe. While in Europe, he met with the Chofetz Chaim. He received his ksav semicha from Rav Shimon Shkop. After his marriage, he settled in Dubuque, Iowa for 5 years, then settled in the Bronx. In the mid-1980s, he moved to Boro Park..

Rav Elya Juransky

Rav Elya Juransky, Rosh Yeshiva in Mir, Brooklyn (2005)

Rav Aryeh Mordechai Halberstam

Rav Aryeh Mordechai Halberstam of Shinova (1930)

Rav Simcha Soloveitchik

Rav Simcha Soloveitchik, son of the Bais Halevi (1941)

Rav Raphael Hakohen

Rav Raphael (ben Yekusiel Zilkind) Hakohen of Hamburg (1723-1803). Born in Liphland to Rav Yekusiel Ziskind, the Rav of the town, Reb Raphael was taken to learn with the Shaagas Aryeh, a relative of theirs, in Minsk, at the age of 12. At the age of 19, Rav Raphael replaced his rebbi as Rosh Yeshiva in Minsk. Four years later, he was chosen as Rav of Rakow, and later of Smilowitz. In 1763, he became Rav in Pinsk. There he wrote Toras Yekusiel on Yoreh De’ah, with an appendix of halachos pertaining to agunos. Later he became Rav in Posen, and in 1776 of the three kehillos of Atuna, Hamburg, and Wandsbeck (AH”U). He also authored Sheilos Hakohanim Torah on the avodah of the kohanim, Sh’Ut Veshav Hakohen, Mapei Lahon on the issur of lashon harah, and Daas Kedoshim.

Rav Shlomo Segal

Rav Shlomo Segal, Av Beis Din Polna’ah and Lvov, he authored MiBeis Levi (1638) [Hamodia 2007 lists Rav Shlomo Charif, Rav of Lvov, 1637. Hamodia 2015 lists Rav Shlomo Halevi Charif, Rav of Lvov, (22 Cheshvan) 1637]

Rav Kalman Levine

Rav Kalman Levine (1959-2014) was murdered in a terror attack at Kehillas Bnei Torah in the Har Nof neighborhood of Jerusalem, during shacharis. He was born in Kansas City, Missouri. Although not raised in a frum home, he was transformed when he spent six months at a kibbutz after high school and then moved to Los Angeles for college only to drop out after becoming engrossed in Torah study and inspired by an influential rabbi in North Hollywood, Rabbi Zvi Block, who established the first Los Angeles branch of Aish HaTorah. Together with his childhood friend, Rabbi Shimon Kraft, Levine travelled to Israel to learn Torah. They attended two years of yeshiva before they returned to Los Angeles to attend a post-high school study program at Yeshiva University Los Angeles (YULA). He decided to return to Israel again in the early 1980s—this time he never left. Over the years in Jerusalem, Levine built a family and continued pursuing the passion of his life—Torah.

Rav Moshe Twersky

Rav Moshe (ben Yitzchok) Twersky (1955-2014) was brutally murdered on November 18th in an attack on his shul while he was  wrapped in tallis and tefillin and immersed in prayer. On his mother’s side, he was the grandson of Rav Yosef Dov Soloveichik, head of Yeshiva University. On his father’s side, he was the grandson of Rav Meshullam Twersky, the Tolner rebbe of Boston. Rav Moshe Twersky was a rebbe and Rosh Kollel in Yeshivas Toras Moshe for 22 years. Rav Soloveitchik once related that since the Shagas Aryeh there hasn’t been a masmid like his grandson Rav Moshe. The irony is that until his death he made sure to maintain his "obscurity" and "anonymity" and it seems that really only his immediate family, a few of his elite teachers and mentors, only his very closest students at the Toras Moshe Yeshiva he taught at for at least 20 years, and maybe a handful of his neighbors and some select colleagues knew about him. He was regarded by the current Brisker Yeshiva of Rav Dovid Soloveitchik as one of its greatest talmidim.

Rav Elya Yurkanski 

Rav Elya Yurkanski (1908-2005). Born in Minsk, he and two brothers were smuggled over the order to Poland, on a recommendation by the Chofetz Chaim; Reb Elya was not yet  a Bar Mitzvah, and he would never again see his parents. He spent almost 10 years in Baranovich with Rav Elchonon Wasserman before leaving for Mir in 1929. He traveled with the yeshiva to Shanghai and eventually joined the yeshiva in New York, where he remained his entire life. He was a Rosh Yeshiva with Mir for over 55 years.

Rav Mordechai Rokeach

Rav Mordechai (ben Yissachar Ber) Rokeach, Rav of Bilgoria (Bilgoraya) (1949). He was the brother of the 4th Admor of Belz (Rav Aharon). Rav Yissachar Dov, a son of Rav Mordechai Rokeach, is the 5th and present Rebbe.

Dates.subjectDescription:
Rav Avraham

Rav Avraham (ben Shlomo Zalman), brother of the Vilna Gaon, author of Maalos Hatorah (1807)

Rav Nachum Dov HaKohen Kreisman

Rav Nachum Dov HaKohen Kreisman (1923-2004). Born in the town of Rakishok in Lithuania's Ponovezh District from a famous line of rabbonim who served in the Rakishok rabbinate for nine consecutive generations, ending with HaRav Betzalel Yalovetzky. As a bochur he went to Yeshivas Telz, where he studied under Rav Eliyahu Meir Bloch. He settled in Baltimore and enrolled at Ner Yisrael, where he studied under Rav Yaakov Yitzchak Ruderman. When Rav Aharon Kotler came to Baltimore, Rav Ruderman sent two bochurim to the train station to meet him: Nachum Dov and Shmuel Kamenetsky. Noting the high caliber of the two young men Rav Kotler took them back with him to New York in preparation for starting Yeshivas Lakewood. In 1954, Rav Kreisman moved to Eretz Yisrael and married, and in 1967, he was chosen to serve as a dayan by Rav Yosef Shalom Eliashiv, Rav Betzalel Zolti, the Rav of Yerushalayim, and Rav Shlomo Shimshon Karelitz.

Rav Raphael Dovid Auerbach

Rav Raphael Dovid (ben Chaim Yehuda Leib) Auerbach, Rosh Yeshiva of Shaar Shomayim (1987)

Rav Gedalya Moshe Goldman

Rav Gedalya Moshe (ben Shlomo) Goldman of Zvhil (1888-1949), son of Reb Shlomke of Zhvil. When the Soviets rose to power, he was sent to Siberia and after eight years of exile managed, in 1936, to flee to Eretz Yisrael, where he also concealed his greatness. He served as an Admor for only five years, for he died when he was only 61.

Rav Hillel Moshe Meshel Gelbstein

Rav Hillel Moshe Meshel (ben Tzvi Hersh) Gelbstein [or Glebstein] (1834-1904 or 1907), born in Bialystok, his mother was a 12th generation descendent of the Shlah HaKodesh. At the age of 15, he traveled to Kotzk and became of chassid of the Kotzker Rebbe. After the Kotzker passed away, Rav Meshel adopted the Chidushei HaRim as his rebbe. On the 23rd of Adar of 1867, the Chidushei HaRim was niftar, and on the 13th of Nissan that same year, the Tzemach Tzedek was niftar. Considering himself orphaned, Rav Meshel moved to Eretz Yisrael and settled in Yerushalayim – he would never again sleep outside the walls of the city. His sefarims included Mishkenos Le’abir Yaakov, Ohr Leyesharim, and Ohr Zarua Latzadik.

Rav Dovid Twersky

Rav Dovid Twersky of Makarov (1902). Makarov is located in Kievskaya, 28 km from Kiev. The earliest known Jewish community was 1765. 1897 Hasidic population (census) was 3953. The Twersky Chasidic dynasty began in Makarov with a Nachum Twersky (1805-1851). Decimated in the Holocaust, Makarov is an offshoot of the Chernobyl dynasty.

Rav Chaim Yosef Brukstein

Rav Chaim Yosef Brukstein of Pistin (1864).

Rav Raphael Kohen

Rav Raphael Kohen of Hamburg (1722-1803). Rosh Yeshiva in Minsk at the age of 19, Rav Raphael became Rav of Pinsk in 1763. In 1776, he became Rav of the joint community of Altoona, Hamburg, and Wandsbek (AHU). He is the author of Toras Yekusiel.

Rav Gedaliah

Rav Gedaliah of Zalkaa (1763).

Binyamin ben Yaakov Avinu

Binyamin ben Yaakov Avinu, buried near Kfar Saba

Rav David Messas

Rav David (ben Shalom) Messas, Chief Rabbi of Paris (1934-2011). Born in Meknes, Morocco, his father was the Chief Rabbi of Morocco. Rav David learned at Aix Les Baines in France, under Rav Yitzchak Chaikin, a talmid of the Chofetz Chaim. He was the Chief Rabbi of Geneva, Switzerland before taking the Chief Rabbi position in Paris in 1995. He also served as Av Beis Din in Paris.

Rav Yaakov Dovid Gordon

Rav Yaakov Dovid (ben Yehuda) Gordon, Chief Rabbi of Norfolk, Virginia (1873-1948). Born in a suburb of Kovno, he was orphaned of his father at the age of five and lived with his uncle. After his Bar Mitzvah, he began to learn at Telshe Yeshiva. After serving as Rav in Chicago for a year and a half, he was appointed Rav of Norfolk, a position he held for the last 40 years of his life. He authored several sefarim including Dor VaDorshav and Zichron Yaakov. He was buried in Union Field Cemetary in Queens.

Rav Moshe Midner

Rav Moshe (ben Yaakov Leib) Midner of Slonim-Baranowitz (1929), a grandson of the Yesod Ha'avodah and a talmid of Rav Chaim Brisker. He was mashgiach of Yeshivas Toras Chessed. The chassidim of Slonim used to say of him “From Moshe (of Midian) up until Moshe Midner, there was none like Moshe.”

Rav Yehosef Rottenberg

Rav Yehosef (ben Tzvi) Rottenberg of Kosson (1912 or 1911 per Hamodia 2012). Author of Bnei Shileishim.

Rav Avraham Chaim Horowitz

Rav Avraham Chaim (ben Menachem Mendel) Horowitz of Linsk (1904)

Rav Raphael Yosef Chazzan

Rav Raphael Yosef Chazzan (ben Chayim) of Izhmir, Rishon L'Tzion of Yerushalayim, author of Teshuvos Chikrei Lev (1820).

Rav Aharon Katzenellenbogen

Rav Aharon Katzenellenbogen of Brisk, author of Minchas Aharon (1777).

Rav Uriel Davidi 

Rav Uriel Davidi [aka "Hacham Uriel"] (1925-2005). The 14th of 14 children, 9 of whom died in childhood (while 3 others died in early adulthood). His mother, Serach, begged Hashem for a healthy son that would be a talmid chacham. Rav Uriel had a photographic memory and great analytic ability, despite having had only four years of structured schooling due to their refusal is accept him. He was home-schooled by his esteemed father Hacham Meir and attended the Chedder aka Mollaie and learned Persian writing and literature plus Arabic and Islamic law from his tutors, a sheikh and his wife! This came in handy later after the Iranian revolution and his dealings with Ayatollahs . Rav Uriel lost his father at 17, and married his first cousin at 18. Rav Uriel moved to Tehran at age 27 and became one of the two main rabbis of the city. He was an expert in Tanach & Midrash, and edited and completed a Hebrew-Persian dictionary. He was an expert Mohel and taught in Otzar Hatorah schools for over 30 years. He officiated in all life cycle events but was most well-known and sought after for his vast knowledge,  oratory skills and method of delivery.  He had a large library and owned one of only three sets of Shas in Iran.  He was personally responsible for saving several people from certain death by execution.  When he left Iran in 1994, over one thousand Sefarim had to be left behind; only his Midrash Rabbah and Torah Temima he took to Israel.

Rav Yissachar Dov Rokeach

Rav Yissachar Dov (ben Yehoshua) Rokeach, the third Belzer rebbe (1854-1926), known by the chassidim as "Reb Socher Ber." One of Rav Yissachar Dov's best known chassidim was a woman, Sarah Schneirer, who in 1917 founded the "Bais Yaakov" movement with the Rebbe's blessing.  By 1937 Bais Yaakov had 38,000 students in 250 cities. Rav Yissachar Dov succeeded his father as head of the Machzikei Hadas movement, an organization founded by Rav Yehoshua Rokeach and Rav Shimon Sofer to strengthen Torah observance in Galicia.

Rav Azreil Halevi Horowitz 

Rav Azreil (ben Dov) Halevi Horowitz (1818), known as the "Eizener Kop" (“Rosh Habarzel” in Hebrew) when he served as Chief Rabbi of Lublin. Opposed the Chozeh when the latter arrived in Lublin.

Rav Dovid Shlomo Eibshitz

Rav Dovid Shlomo (ben Yerachmiel) Eibshitz (1755-1813), author of Levushei Serad (on halacha), Arvei Nachal (a Torah commentary with Chasidic philosophy), Neos Deshe on teshuva, Megillas Setarim (mussar work based on first perek in Tehillim), and many other works. He served as Rosh Yeshiva in Nadvorna in 1780, Rav in Budzhanov in 1790, then Rav of Soroka. In 1809, he settled in Tzefas, Israel, where he died and is buried.

Rav Yissachar Dov Beirish Falk 

Rav Yissachar Dov Beirish (ben Yaakov Yehoshua) Falk (1744), son of the P'nei Yehoshua.

Rav Moshe Lima

Rav Moshe (ben Yitzchak Yehuda) Lima, author of Chelkas Mechokek (1656). First Rav of Slonim. While there, he was considered the highest authority in halacha in all of Lithuania. He later served as Rav in Lvov, Brisk and Vilna.

Rav Moshe Reichman

Rav Moshe (Paul) (ben Shmayahu) Reichman (1930-2013).  Born in Vienna and raised in the family’s wartime refuge of Moroccan Tangier, he was a talmid of the renowned Gateshead and Ponovezh Yeshivos where he attained semicha at nineteen years of age and was directly influenced by many current and future Gedolei Yisroel, including the Chazan Ish and Rav Shach, the latter of whom Reb Reichmann regarded as his Rebbe muvhak. Shortly after his marriage, the Reichmann family immigrated to Montreal, Canada and ultimately settled in Toronto where they raised their five children. Mr. Reichmann’s success in business was nothing short of legendary as he led his family’s company, Olympia & York in its rise to prominence on the global stage through their innovative and skyline changing real estate developments in Toronto, New York and London. However, his business accomplishments were dwarfed by his focus on chesed as the broader Reichmann family gave an estimated $1 billion to charity. His drive to support the world’s Torah institutions as well as honor Torah scholars and Gedolei Yisroel was matched with his extreme sensitivity to the individual baal habayis challenged to pay his bills. The stories of Reb Reichmann and his siblings discreetly financing weddings, housing purchases and the like number in the tens of thousands. His name will forever invoke the requirement of how one should go the extra mile to help another in a dignified and honorable fashion.

Rav Yitzchak Nosson Kupershtock

Rav Yitzchak Nosson (ben Yehuda Yaakov) Kupershtock (1922-2011). As a youth, he learned at Yeshivas Etz Chaim under Rav Isser Zalman Meltzer. His rebbi muvhak was the Tchebiner Rav. At the age of 34, he published his first sefer, Meoros Nosson, on the halachos of various topics including electricity on Shabbos; he had discussed many technicalities with scientists in doing background research. Other topics include hadlakos neiros, hilchos Purim, and hilchos Chanukkah.

Rav Mordechai Elefant

Rav Mordechai Elefant, Rosh Yeshiva of ITRI Yerushalayim (2009).

Rav Betzalel Stern

Rav Betzalel (ben Avraham) Stern (1910-1988). Born in Neihiezel, Czechoslovakia to the author of Melitzei Aish, he accepted his first rabbinic post in Seben, Transylvania, where he also headed the yeshiva. In 1954, he moved to Melbourne, Australia to serve as Rav of the Adas Yisrael community. After 14 years, he moved, primarily because most of his family lived in Eretz Yisrael, a distance too difficult to accommodate. He moved to Vienna to serve as Rav. In 1982, he moved to Yerushalayim, leaving his son, Chaim, as Rav of Vienna. He was the author of the six-volume She’eilos U’Teshuvos B’Tzel Hachochma. He was also a brother of Rav Moshe Stern.

Rav Moshe

Rav Moshe of Shitchelnik (1912)

Rav Elazar HaKohen

Rav Elazar HaKohen of Poltusk (1881)

Rav Yissacher Ber

Rav Yissacher Ber of Podheitz, son of the Pnei Yehoshua (1844)

Rav Yichya Halevi Alshich

Rav Yichya Halevi Alshich, head of Yemenite community

Rav Avraham Azulai

Rav Avraham (ben Mordechai) Azulai, author of Chessed  L’Avraham (1569 [or 1570]-1643), which is often quoted in the writings of the Ari HaKodesh. Born in Fez, Morocco, he moved to Chevron in 1609 and became the city’s Chief Rabbi. In 1619, a cholera epidemic broke out, and he moved to Yerushalayim, then back to Chevron, and eventually, to Azah (Gaza). It was in Azah that he wrote Chessed L'Avraham. Later he returned to Chevron again. He wrote other works including Ahavah Bata’anugim on the Mishna and Or Hachamah on the Zohar. Rav Avraham was the great, great-grandfather of the Chida.  [according to some, his yahrtzeit is 24 or 25 Cheshvan]

 

 

Born in Fez, his grandfather having settled there after being expelled from Castille, Spain, in 1492. In 1700, he fulfilled his life’s dream and boarded a ship for Eretz Yisrael. The only possessions he took him were the many manuscripts of his chiddushim. These were all lost at sea during a storm. In Chevron, Rav Avraham wrote his major work on Kabbalah, entitled Kiryat Arba. It is based on the teachings of the four great kabbalists: the Ramak, the Arizal, Rav Chaim Vital and Rav Avraham Galanti. Later, in Aza (Gaza), Rav Avraham composed three more sefarim: Baalei Bris Avraham, a commentary on the twenty-four books of the Tanach, and Chessed l'Avraham, which contains kabbalistic drashos. In addition to this, he wrote Kanaf Renanim, a summary of the kavanos of the prayers according to the Arizal; Ma'aseh Chosheiv, a summary of the kavanos of the Arizal on the mitzvos; Ahavah BaTa'anugim on the Mishnah, and Hagahos l'Sefer HaLevush on the Shulchan Aruch.

Rav Dovid Ben Zimra

Rav Dovid (ben Shlomo) Ben Zimra, the Radbaz (1480-1573). Arriving in Tzefas as a child after the Spanish expulsion, he emigrated to Egypt in 1514. Shortly thereafter, he was recognized as chief rabbi of Egypt, a post he held for 40 years. His income, however, came through business, from which he became quite wealthy. Among his talmidim in Cairo were Rav Yitzchak Luiria (the Ari) and Rav Betazelel Azhkenazi, the Shita Mekubetzes. In 1553, he returned to Eretz Yisrael, settling in Tzefas.

Rav Mordechai Leib Zuckerman

Rav Mordechai Leib Zuckerman, author of Meir Einei Yisrael (1912-2003). Born in Samagron, a city near Vilna. In 1931, he moved to Radin to learn with the Chofetz Chaim. After the petirah of the Chofetz Chaim, Rav Mordechai Leib stayed in Radin for eight more years. During the war, he arrived in the Kovno ghetto, where he acted as shamash for Rav Avraham Grodzinsky, the mashgiach of Slabodka. As Rav Avraham's talmid muvhak, he transcribed his mentor's discourses and studied with him privately bechavrusa when Rav Avraham was hospitalized. Subsequently, the Nazis burned down that hospital and Rav Mordechai Leib was the last person to have seen Rav Avraham alive. When the Nazis decided to liquidate the entire ghetto, Rav Mordechai Leib was saved by a miracle when he hid in a pit with a few others. In 1948, he moved to Yerushalayim. When he settled in Givat Shaul, he accepted the positions of rav of the Perushim shul and the head of Kollel Chevron there. He occupied those positions for over 50 years.

Rav Mordechai Sharabi

Rav Mordechai (ben Yehuda) Sharabi (1912-1984). Born in Taiz, Yemen, his father was niftar before he was born, and his mother passed away just 4 years later. He was raised by his grandfather, Rav Yefes Avraham, Rav in Sharab. Rav Mordechai’s other grandfather was Rav Salom Sharabi, the Rashash. In 1931, shortly after he married, Rav Mordechai moved to Eretz Yisrael and settled in Yerushalayim. He later founded Yeshivat Nahar Shalom in the Machane Yehuda section of the city. Although they never had children, tens of boys of the neighborhood had their meals with them and grew to become Roshei Yeshiva and Roshei Kollel. It is related that in the week of Rav Mordechai’s petira, the Baba Sali experienced a frightening premonition that much Jewish blood would be spilled, including children. He davened the entire day and fasted despite being over 90 years of age. The next morning, he announced that the gezeira was lifted, and that one of the tzadikim gave his life away for the generation. At the time, the Baba Sali was not aware that Rav Mordechai was ill. Indeed, the tzadik was niftar that week.

Rav Moshe Nassan Nota Lemberger

Rav Moshe Nassan Nota (ben Menachem Mendel) Lemberger, the Makava Rav of Kfar Ata (1982)

Rav Yechezkel HaKohen Rabinowitz

Rav Yechezkel (ben Avraham Yissachar Ber) HaKohen Rabinowitz, the third Rebbe of Radmosk, known as the Kenesses Yechezkel of Radomsk (1864-1910)

Rav Meshulam Yissachar Horowitz

Rav Meshulam Yissachar (ben Aryeh Leib HaLevi) Horowitz of Stanislav (1887), author of Bar Levai.

Rav Shalom HaLevi Rosenfeld

Rav Shalom (ben Yaakov Yosef) HaLevi Rosenfeld of Kaminka (1851)

Rav Avraham ben Dovid

Rav Avraham ben Dovid (Ravad III) (1119-1198). Rav Avraham lived at the time of Rabbeinu Tam and is mentioned a few times in the Tosafos. He had the merit of having Eliyahu HaNavi appear to him, as claimed by Rav Chaim Vital in his introduction to Etz HaChaim. His son was the tzaddik Rabbi Yitzchak Sagi Nahor.

Rav Avraham ben Yitzchak

Rav Avraham ben Yitzchak of Narbonne (c. 1110 – 1179), (Ravad II) author of Sefer HaEshkol, father-in-law of the the Raavad III, Rav Avraham ben Dovid.

Rav Avraham Tzvi Hirsch Kamai

Rav Avraham Tzvi Hirsch (ben Eliyahu Baruch) Kamai, the last Rav of Mir (1859-1942). Born in the Lithuanian town of Shkod, his family traced its ancestry back to the brother of the Vilna Gaon, Rav Avraham, author of Maalos Hatorah.His father was the Rav of of the communities of Shkod, Karelitz and Czechnovtza, following which he served as Rav of Mir and as head of the town's yeshiva. His chiddushim were published in Bris Melach. Rav Tzvi Hirsch’s wife,  who was a clever and highly-educated woman, opened a pharmacy in order to support the family. Rav Tzvi Hirsch assisted her from time to time when she needed help, and he would also prepare medicines for the customers according to the prescriptions that they brought. With his father’s petira, however, he replaced as Rav and Rosh Yeshiva in Mir.

Rav Sa’asa Hakohen

Rav Sa’asa Hakohen of Djerba, Tunisia (1904)(Hamodia 2014)

Rav Moshe Michel

Rav Moshe Michel (ben Eliezer Fishel) of Biala (1854). After his marriage, Rav Moshe Michel settled in Zamoszh, where he and his wife were supported by her father. After the passing of his father in 1812, he became a chassid of the Chozeh of Lublin, and then Rav Bunim of Peshischa. He eventually became Rav of Biala.

Rav Eliyahu Rogler

Rav Eliyahu (ben Yaakov) Rogler, Rav of Slobodka and Kalisch (1794-1849). Born in Soginad, near Zamut in Lithuania, he was a talmid of Rav Chaim Volozhiner. His first rabbinic post was at Shott, near Kaidan. In 1821, he was appointed Rav of Rogoli, the city from which he took his surname. Three years later, he became Rav and Rosh Yeshiva of the city of William-Pally, near Kovno. In 1840, he was appointed Rav of Kalisch, where he remained the rest of his life. Many of his teshuvos were published as Shu”T Yad Eliyahu. He was buried near the kever of the Magen Avraham.

Rav Shimshon Halevi Heller

Rav Shimshon Halevi Heller of Zhbarizh (1839). Zbarazh is a city in the Ternopil Oblast of western Ukraine (formerly in eastern Galicia). Jews were living there at the end of the 15th century. A synagogue was erected in the 17th century. The siege on Zbarazh by Chmielnicki in 1649, its capture by the Turks in 1676, and the Haidamak raids of 1708 caused terrible suffering to the community. There were 910 Jewish inhabitants in 1765. The number increased under Austrian rule after 1772, reaching 2,896 (35% of the total population) in 1900. The 1931 census records 3,000 Jewish residents.

Rav Yitzchak Avraham Wallerstein

Rav Yitzchak Avraham (ben Asher) Wallerstein of Minsk, brother of the Shaagas Aryeh (1775)

Rav Naftali Yitzchak Segal

Rav Naftali Yitzchak Segal, author of Naftali Seva Ratzon (1555)

Rav Nechemiah Kibel

Rav Nechemiah Kibel (1952-2005). Born in Memphis, Tennessee, to Holocaust survivors, R’ Kibel entered the newly founded Yeshiva of the South, under Rav Meir Belsky, who was one of the first talmidim of Rav Yitzchak Hutner. He served as a magid shiur at the yeshiva in Memphis, then founded and taught at RITSS (Regional Institute for Torah and Secular Studies), Cincinnati’s Bais Yaakov in 1989. A few later, he played a major role in the founding of  Cincinnati’s Community Kollel.

Rav Nachum Pertzovitz

Rav Nachum (ben Aryeh Tzvi) Pertzovitz (Partzovitz),  Rosh Yeshivas Mir Yerushalayim (1922-1986). At the age of 9, he attended Ramailles Yeshiva in Vilna under Rav Shlomo Heiman. Five years later, he learned at Kaminetz, and Rav Baruch Ber Leibowitz became his rebbi muvhak. He joined the Mir yeshiva in its exile in Shanghhai, during which his chavrusa was Rav Shmuel Berenbaum. After the War, he traveled to Eretz Yisrael and married Ettel, the daughter of Rav Chaim Shmulevitz and grand-daughter of Rav Lazer Yudel Finkel. He wrote Divrei Eliyahu, based on several years of listening to Rav Finkel’s Shabbos shiurim and writing them down motzoei Shabbos; the sefer includes Rav Nachum’s footnotes.

Rav Raphael Baruch Toledano

Rav Raphael Baruch (ben Yaakov) Toledano of Morocco, author of Sephardic Kitzur Shulchan Aruch (1890-1970 [1971, per Hamodia 2010]). Born in Meknes, Morocco, his poem, Ashorer Shira Lichvod Hatorah – written as a youth – became a classic and is sung among Sephardic Jews til today. Even before his father’s petira, he took personal responsibility for all aspects of Jewish life – mikvaos, Talmud Torah, old age homes – in every part of Morocco, from Marrakesh to Rabat, from Casablanca to Tangiers. After his father’s petira in 1928, he became Rav and Av Beis Din. After World War I, when Morocco became a French protectorate, Rav Toledano fought the secularists of the Alliance schools. He even established a kiruv rechokim organization called Shuvu Banim. Towards the end of his life, in 1963, he immigrated to Eretz Yisrael.

Rav Yaakov Friedman

Rav Yaakov (ben Yitzchak) Friedman of Bohush-Husyatin (1956). Author of Ahalei Yaakov.

Rav Yishayah Bardaky

Rav Yishayah Bardaky (1862). Rav Bardaky was born in Pinsk and taught Torah there, but he decided to settle in Eretz Yisrael after his first wife died. When the ship carrying Rav Bardaky, his son, Shmuel Akiva, and his daughter, neared the port of Akko, it was wrecked, and all the passengers were thrown into the sea. Rav Bardaky, however, was a powerful swimmer, and, with his two children on his back, he swam ashore. Upon reaching Yerushalayim, Rav Bardaky was appointed head of the Ashkenazic community. He also was appointed vice-consul of the Austrian Empire.

Rav Tzvi Pruzansky

Rav Tzvi (ben Binyamin) Pruzansky (2005). He helped found the Toronto Kollel, and established, along with his friend, Rav Dovid Hersh Mayer zt"l, Yeshivas Beis Binyamin in Stamford, which was named after Rav Tzvi's father and funded by Rav Tzvi's brothers, ybl"c, Reb Yosef and Reb Moshe.

Rav Meshulam Zushe Twersky

Rav Meshulam Zushe (ben Chaim Yitzchak) Twersky, the Chernobyler Rebbe of Bnei Brak (1917-1987). An eighth generation direct descendent of the Rav Menachem Nachum of Chernobyl, Rav Meshulam Zushe was born in Mozyr, Belarus. He lived and learned with his maternal grandfather, the Admor of Tchetchov, Rav Yeshaya Halberstam, the youngest son of the Divrei Chaim. In 1959, he moved his court to Bnai Brak. He was succeeded by his son, Rav Menachem Nachum.

Rav Reuven HaKohen Katz

Rav Reuven (ben Shimon) HaKohen Katz, Rav of Petach Tikva and author of Degel Reuven. His son, Rav Leizer Katz, was a rav in Passaic, New Jersey, for many years until his petira in 2001.

Rav Yehoshua Rosenfeld

Rav Yehoshua (ben Shalom) Rosenfeld of Kaminka (1898)

Rav Mordechai Zev Orenstein

Rav Mordechai Zev Orenstein, Rav and Av Beis Din of Lelov (1836).

Rav Menachem Mendel Hager

Rav Menachem Mendel (ben Yaakov Koppel) Hager of Kosov (1768-1825), founder of the Vizhnitz and Kosov dynasties and author of Ahavas Shalom. Rav Menachem Mendel was a student of Rav Moshe Leib of Sassov, Rav Tzvi Hirsch of Nadvorna, and Rav Ze’ev Wolfe of Tcharne-Ostra. His grandson was Rav Menachem Mendel of Vizhnitz.

Rav Yaakov Koppel

Rav Yaakov Koppel of Tismenitz (1823), a talmid of Rav Moshe Leib of Sassov.

Rav Avraham Rappaport

Rav Avraham Rappaport, author of Minchah Belulah (1596).

Rav (Reb) Shlomo Carlebach

Rav (Reb) Shlomo Carlebach (1925-1994), the foremost Jewish songwriter in the 2nd half of the 20th century, who used his music to inspire Jews around the world. Over his 69 years, he lived in Manhattan, San Francisco, Toronto and Moshav Or Modiin, Israel. In a recording career that stretched over 30 years, Reb Shlomo sang his songs on more than 25 albums. Shlomo Carlebach was born in Berlin, where his father, Naftali, was an Orthodox leader. The family, which fled the Nazis in 1933, lived in Switzerland before coming to New York in 1939. His father became the rabbi of a small synagogue on West 79th Street, Congregation Kehlilath Jacob; Shlomo Carlebach and his twin brother, Eli Chaim, took over the synagogue after their father's death in 1967. He studied at the Yeshiva Torah Vodaath in Brooklyn and at the Bais Medrash Gavoah in Lakewood, N.J. From 1951 to 1954, he worked as a traveling emissary of the Grand Rabbi of Lubavitch, Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson. His singing career began in Greenwich Village, where he met Bob Dylan and other folk singers, and moved to Berkeley for the 1966 Folk Festival. After his appearance, he decided to remain in the Bay Area to reach out to what he called "lost Jewish souls," runaways and drug addicted youths.

Rav Elazar Menachem Mann Shach

Rav Elazar Menachem Mann (ben Azriel) Shach (1898 [some say 1894]-2001). Born in Vaboilnick, Lithuania, and left for Ponevezh (38km away) at age 7. Learned at Slabodka under Rav Yechezkel Bernstein (Divrei Yechezkel), then under the Alter (Rav Nosson Tzvi Finkel), and developed a close relationship with Rav Isser Zalman Meltzer, whose niece Rav Shach eventually married. In 1927, he served as Rosh Mesivta at Kletzk under Rav Aharon Kotler, holding the same position at Novardok from 1932-34. In 1951, he started his career as Rosh Yeshiva at Ponevezh under Rav Yosef Kahanemen. Among his sefarim are Avi Ezri (on Rambam's Mishneh Torah), Rosh Amanah (insights on chumash), and Michtavim U'ma'amarim and B'zos Ani Botaiach (the latter two are collections of letters and speeches).

Rav Amram Chassida Yisrael Betzalel Rosenbaum

Rav Amram (ben Moshe Nachum) Chassida Yisrael Betzalel Rosenbaum (1790-1829). Born in Hungary, served as rabbi of Mad, Hungary, and moved to Eretz Yisrael at the age of 36, setting in Tzefas. However, he lived in Eretz Yisrael for only four years, and passed away in 1830. His  daughter was among the 500 Tzefat residents killed by an earthquake in 1832.

Rav Michoel Forshlager

Rav Michoel (ben Avraham Moishe) Forshlager (1884-1959). He  was accepted as one of the youngest talmidim to the beis midrash of the Avnei Nezer in Sokotchov, staying until 1910. Well before the age of 30, he was regarded as one of the gedolei hador. Rav Forshlager and his family arrived in Baltimore in 1921. In the 1930s, he had a pivotal role in convincing Rav Yaakov Yitzchok Ruderman, who was visiting Baltimore as a shliyach of  the Rabbinical Seminary of Cleveland, to start a yeshiva in Baltimore. Soon, Ner Israel was founded. According to Rav Avraham Aharon Preis of Toronto, the last of the Sokatchover talmidim, the kisvei yad that Rav Forshlager left (45 bound volumes of about 300 pages each, plus around 1,000 pages unbound) were written over a period of 10 to 15 years. Rav Forshlager’s library, which contained approximately 7,000 volumes, was purchased by Yad Harav Herzog with a stipulation that a volume must be published within five years. The sefer that was issued was named Toras Michoel.

Rav Avraham Yeshaya Karelitz

Rav Avraham Yeshaya (ben Shmaryahu Yosef) Karelitz, the Chazon Ish (1878-1953). Educated by his father, the Av Beis Din in Kosova, Poland (near Grodno), his first work on several parts of the Shulchan Aruch was published anonymously in Vilna in 1911 under the title "Chazon Ish," by which name he became known. He moved to Vilna about 1920 and moved to Eretz Yisrael in 1933, settling in Bnei B'rak. Upon his arrival in Eretz Yisrael, he devoted vast amounts of time and energy to Seder Zeraim, which deals mainly with laws pertaining to the land, to answer the many halachic problems inherent to a life in the Holy Land consistent with Torah.

Rav Chaim Pinto

Rav Chaim Pinto the Second was born in Mogador (current Essaouira), Morocco (-1939). His grandfather, Rav Chaim the First, was the great-grandson of Rav Yosef Pinto, who fled from Spain to Rome with 26 talmidim after the 1492 expulsion. However, he had to flee to Damascus after local priests trapped him into a theological debate and soundly lost. When the Jewish population of Mogador began thinning out, Rav Chaim the Second moved to Casablanca, while his son, Rav Moshe Aharon Pinto, stayed Mogador to prevent his father’s shul from closing down.

Rav Shmuel Frenkel

Rav Shmuel (ben Shraga Feivel) Frenkel of Dorog [or Kamada], [Hungary] the Imrei Shefer (1881) [Hamodia 2005 says 1921] His father-in-law was the Belzer Rav. Dorog is a small town in Komárom-Esztergom, Hungary, in the valley between the Pilis and Gerecse mountains. When Hungary's kings resided at Esztergom in the 11th and 12th centuries, Dorog was where the cooks of the castle lodged. His great, great-grandson, Rav Yidel Frenkel, built the Imrei Shefer Shul and Yeshiva in the Har Nof area of Yerushalayim. [Other sefarim by the same name: Imrei Shefer, by Rav Avraham Abulafia, 1291, which deals with the system of Tzerufim – written in the island of Komino near Malta in 1291, it was his last book; Imrei Shefer al HaTorah - Rabbi Shlomo Kluger of Brod (1785-1869); Imrei Shefer: Pirket Avot, by Rav Shmuel Pinchasi, the Rav of Yerushalayim's Machane Yehuda neighborhood. He is the founder and Rosh Kollel of Yeshiva Darchei Dovid. He is a worldwide halachic advisor and dayan; Teshuvos Imrei Shefer by Rav Eliyahu Klatzkin; Imrei Shefer by Rav Naftali Hertz Landau, originally printed in the city of Lvov in the year 1883.]

Rav Leib Baal HaYisurim

Rav Leib Baal HaYisurim in Tzefas (1836). He is buried in Tzefas, and he offered a havtacha for yeshuos to all who daven at his kever.

Rav Elazar Kalir

Rav Elazar Kalir (1801). Chief Rabbi of Rechnitz and Kilan (or Kelen), author of Or Chadash on Shas. He also published a sefer by his grandfather, the Paanim Me’iros, called K’sonos Or; the sefer includes his own ammendations

Rav Tzvi HaLevi Horowitz

Rav Tzvi (ben Meir) HaLevi Horowitz, Chief Rabbi of Chortkov, father of Reb Shmelke of Nikolsburg and the Baal Haflaa (1753)

Rav Eliezer ben Yitzchak ibn Archa

Rav Eliezer ben Yitzchak ibn Archa (1651). Born in Tzefas, he moved to Chevron, where he served as Rav of the small Jewish population for most of his life. According to the Chida, he wrote many works including a commentary on Ein Yaakov and on Midrash Rabbah.

Mattisyahu ben Yochanan

Mattisyahu ben Yochanan, Kohen Godol, father of the Chasmonaim (138 BCE, or 165)

Rav Aharon Weiss

Rav Aharon Weiss of Benedkwits (1851-1932). At the age of 20, he became Rav of Benedkwits, a town near Munkatch. He opened a yeshiva there. In 1907, he moved his yeshiva to Raswigeff region of Munkatch, where he served as Rav and Dayan.

Rav Yehuda Aryeh Lowy

Rav Yehuda Aryeh Lowy (or Loew), grandfather of the Maharal (1539)

Rav Tzvi Shraga Grossbard

Rav Tzvi Shraga Grossbard (1916-1993) was born in Visan, Lithuania. His father, Rav Aharon Zev, was an outstanding talmid of the Chofetz Chaim. When Tzvi Shraga was still a youngster, his father was brutally beaten to death by Lithuanian thugs because he refused to inform on a fellow Jew. At the age of nine Tzvi Shraga joined Yeshivas Sha'arei Torah in Grodna. At age 14, Rav Tzvi Shraga entered Grodna's yeshiva gedola and formed a close bond with the famed Rav Shimon Shkop. Afterwards, he became one of Rav Baruch Ber Lebowitz's select students in Yeshivas Kaminetz, and at the beginning of the Second World War he studied for a year and a half under Rav Daniel Movshovitz in Yeshivas Kelm. In 1941, Rav Tzvi Shraga left Europe for Eretz Yisrael. There, he joined the Lomza yeshiva in Petach Tikvah headed by his uncle, Rav Abba Grossbard. Rav Tzvi Shraga also became the head of Tel Aviv's beis mussar and developed a strong friendship with mussar giant, Rav Eliyahu Dessler who was then spiritual mashgiach of the Ponovezh Yeshiva. The two men studied b'chavrusa each week in Rav Tzvi Shraga's home. In 1967 Rav Tzvi Shraga Grossbard became the director of Chinuch Atzmai and he remained at its helm for 25 years,

Rav Haim Nahum Effendi

Rav Haim Nahum Effendi (1872-1960). Served as Sephardic Chief Rabbi of Egypt (1925-1960). He was witness both to a vibrant community of 80,000 Jews living in Egypt and also to the community's disintegration after 1948 when government hostility, violence, economic restrictions, confiscation and deportation caused most Jews to leave. Born near Izmir in Turkey, he was sent by his parents to learn in  a yeshiva in Tiveriya and later went to a French Lycee for his secondary education, obtaining a degree in Muslim law in Constantinople. He also attended the Sorbonne's School of Oriental Languages, where he perfected his linguistic abilities and also studied history and philosophy. In 1923, Rabbi Nahum received an invitation from Moise Cattaoui Pacha, head of the Jewish community in Cairo, to become the Chief Rabbi of Egypt and was appointed to serve as a Senator in the nation's Legislative Assembly.

Rav Yosef Rabinowitz 

Rav Yosef (ben Gedalya Aharon) Rabinowitz (1910). Reached America in 1906, settling in New York, then became the Rav of Buffalo, until his petira. He was buried in the Pine Ridge Cemetary in Buffalo.

Rav Baruch

Rav Baruch (ben Avraham) of Kosov (1782 or 1799). Disciple of the Maggid of Mezritch and of Rav Menachem Mendel of Vitebsk; author of Yesod HaEmunah and Amud HaAvoda.

Rav Yehuda Hachassid

Rav Yehuda Hachassid, author of Sefer Hachassidim (1150-1217). He was born in Speyer (Shapira) and died in Regensburg. His father, Shmuel, was a saintly and renowned Rosh Yeshiva in Speyer, and Rav Yehudah studied under him. He also wrote Sefer Gimatriot and was one of the main teachers of the ‘Chassidei Ashkenaz’. Among his talmidim were the Or Zarua and the Semag.

Rav Yehuda Yehoshua Chaim Tzadka

Rav Yehuda Yehoshua Chaim (ben Shaul) Tzadka, Rosh Yeshiva of Porat Yosef (1909-1991). Born in Yerushalayim, Rav Yehuda was a great-great grandson of Rav Tzadka Chutzin, author of Tzedaka U’misphat. His mother, Simcha, was the Ben Ish Chai’s niece. The Tzadka family lived in the Beis Yisrael neighborhood of Yerushalayim. When he was 12 years old, Yehuda Tzadka enrolled in the Porat Yosef Yeshiva in the Old City. There, he became very close to Rav Ezra Attia. At the age of only 27 years, he was appointed to teach at the yeshiva. Among Reb Yehuda’s first students was Rav Ovadia Yosef. In time, Rav Yehuda became the menahel ruchani, and with the petira of Rav Ezra Attias in 1970, he was appointed to new Rosh Yeshiva.

Rav Yechiel Michel Charlap

Rav Yechiel Michel (ben Yaakov Moshe) Charlap (1899-1974). Born in Yerushalayim, he joined a select group of young men who studied under Rav Yitzchak Yerucham Diskin when he was 16 years old. In 1921, Rav Charlap traveled to New York to study at Yeshiva Rabbeinu Yitzchak Elchanan.  At the same time, he served as Rav of Anshei Volozhin. Later, he served as Rav in Canton, Ohio and, still later, in Omaha, Nebraska.  In 1926, Rav Charlap became Rav of the Bronx Jewish Center, a tenure he held for 48 years. He was also among the founders of the OU's Kashruth Division. In 1951, after his father's death, Rav Charlap was elected Rav of Yerushalayim's Sha'arei Chessed and Rechaviah neighborhoods, but he declined the positions.  Instead, he remained at the Bronx Jewish Center until his death.  He was buried on Har Ha'zeitim.

Rav Moshe Halberstam 

Rav Moshe (ben Yechezkel Shraga) Halberstam of Shinave (1842-1918). Born to the Shinaver Rebbe (the Divrei Yechezkel), the oldest son of the Divrei Chaim of Sanz. Several years before his petirah, the Divrei Chaim appointed him Rav Hatzair if Shinave. He later replaced his father as Rav. He was buried in the ohel at Sanz near the Divrei Chaim.

Rav Aharon Zinger 

Rav Aharon Zinger of Mattersdorf, author of Tiferes Aharon (1868).

Rav Nachum Levi

Rav Nachum Levi (ben Avraham) of Shadik, Yerushalayim (~1811-1865). As a youth, he was a talmid of Rav Shlomo Zalman Lifshitz (the Chemdas Shlomo); he moved to Yerushalayim in 1844. He was the father of the Baharan family that built Meah Shearim, including Rav Dovid Baharan and Rav Shlomo Zalman Baharan. He died in the cholera plague of 1865, which took hundreds of lives. The Yeshivos HaRan network of 18 yeshivos and kollelim is named for him and is headed by his great-grandson, Rav Tzvi Weissfish. Rav Nachum’s chidushim on Bava Metzia were published under the name, Avnei Kodesh, as were his shaylos u’teshuvos.

Rav Moshe Kramer

Rav Moshe Kramer, Av Beis Din in Vilna and grandfather of the GRA. His surname, “Kramer” is derived from the Yiddish word for storekeeper. He owned a store, which his wife ran. And as a result, he always insisted on not being paid for his rabanus (1648 [1687 per Hamodia 2011 and Hamodia 2014]).

Rav Nosson Tzvi Finkel

Rav Nosson Tzvi (ben Eliyahu Meir) Finkel, Rosh Yeshiva of Mir-Yerushalayim (1943-2011). Born in Chicago, he was named for his great-grandfather, the Alter of Slabodka. At the age of 18, he came to Yerushalayim to learn in the Mir under his cousin, Rav Eliezer Yehudah Finkel. He had a learning seder with Rav Zundel Kroizer, in which they finished shas each year. Rav Nosson Tzvi was appointed Rosh Yeshiva in 1990.

Rav Pesach Prushkin

Rav Pesach Prushkin, Rav and Rosh Yeshiva in Kobrin (1879-1939). Born to his widowed mother (he was named after his father, who died several months prior to his birth), he grew up in the home of his mother’s grandfather, Rav Pinchas Michael (Rav in Antipole). In his teens, he joined the yeshiva of the Chofetz Chaim in Radin. He later went to Slobodka and spent a year at Kelm and was also a talmid of Rav Chaim Soloveitchik.  When the Alter of Slobodka selected Slutsk, a large city in White Russia, to place one of his yeshivos, he dispatched Rav Isser Zalman Meltzer as Rosh Yeshiva, with fourteen talmidim - among them Pesach “Kobriner.” Rav Pesach became mashgiach in Slutsk. In 1911, he became Rav of Amtsislav (also called Mistsislav) and also opened a yeshiva there. When the Bolsheviks took over Russia, and his native city of Kobrin was incorporated into Poland by the Soviet-Polish treaty of Riga, 1922, he escaped the Communist rule to Kobrin where he became Rav and opened another yeshiva. Among his talmidim was Rav Moshe Feinstein (in Shklov and Mistislav). A collection of his shiurim were published posthumously (by Rav Noson Zachovsky) as Shiurei Maran Rav Pesach M’Kobrin.

Rav Yehuda Leib Chasman

Rav Yehuda Leib (ben Raphael) Chasman, mashgiach of Yeshivas Chevron (1869-1935). Learned in Kelm under Rabbi Simcha Zissel Ziev, in Volozhin under the Netziv as well as that of the Rabbi Chaim Halevi Soloveichik of Brisk. In 1897, he was brought to serve as the Telz yeshiva's Mashgiach. He established the independent Yeshiva in Shtutshin in 1908. In 1912, he was rabbi of Shtutsin. In his last years, he was the spiritual director of the Slabodka Yeshiva in Hebron and in Jerusalem. In 1926, he became mashgiach at Chevron. Author of Ohr Yohel. Among his talmidin was Rav Shlomo Schwadron.

Rav Menachem Nachum Twersky

He was succeeded by his son, Mordechai, founder of the Chernobyl dynasty, the descendents of which are the Skverer Chasidim, the current Rebbe of whom is Rav Dovid Twersky of New Square, NY. The Chernobyl dynasty includes the rebbes of Chernobyl, Cherkas, Turisk, Talne, Korestchov, Makarov, Skver, Rachmastrivka, Malyn, Hornosteipl, Machnovka, Ozarnetz, and several others.

Binyamin ben Yaakov Avinu

Binyamin ben Yaakov Avinu (1554-1445 BCE) [Hamodia says 1843 BCE] He is one of the four people in history who died without sin, i.e., they died only because death was decreed on man after Adam sinned.  (The other three were Amram, the father of Moshe; Yishai, the father of David; and Kilav/Daniel, a son of David.) The tribe of Binyamin was the first to enter the Yam Suf (Red Sea).  The first king, Shaul, came from Binyamin.  Also, the bet hamikdash was built in Binyamin's territory.

Metushelach ben Chanoch

Metushelach ben Chanoch, grandfather of Noach (3074 BCE – 2105 BCE). Metushelach lived 969 years, longer than any person whose age is recorded in the Torah.  We know the exact date of Metushelach's passing from the verse (Bereishis 7:4), "For in seven more days time I will send rain upon the earth ..." Rashi explains that out of respect for Metushelach, Hashem waited through the seven days of mourning for that tzaddik before bringing the flood.  The flood started on the 17th of Cheshvan. Metushelach taught Torah to Shem, the son of Noach.  Also, the midrash lists Metushelach as one of the "Seven Shepherds" who will serve as mashiach's entourage.

Rav Yisroel Meir Shurkin

Rav Yisroel Meir (ben Yaakov Moishe) Shurkin (2014), a respected talmid chacham, a talmid of Rav Aharon Kotler and Rav Moshe Feinstein. His son, Rav Yaakov Moishe Shurkin, is the author of Sifrei Biur Achizah Be’eikev al Teshuvos Rebbi Akiva Eigerand other seforim.

Rav Eliezer Ehrenreich

Rav Eliezer (ben Chaim Tzvi) Ehrenreich, Mahder Rav (2013). Married in the town of Dezh, Romania, he served as Rav in Mahd for a short time in the 1940s, lived for a few years in DP camps in Germany, and immigrated to the United States in 1949. He was the founder and nasi of Machon Kol Aryeh (named for his great-grandfather). Rav Ehrenreich authored Kav Chaim; Ketzei Hamateh on the classic Mateh Ephraim, on the halachos of Elul and Yamim Nora’im; and Shaarei Chaim on the Shaarei Ephraim. He was buried in the Munkatcher section of the Floral Park Cemetery in Deans, NJ.

Rav Dov Schwatzman

Rav Dov (ben Yehoshua Zev) Schwatzman, Rosh Yeshiva of Bais Hatalmud, Yerushalayim (1921-2011). Born in Nevel, Russia, he moved to Eretz Yisrael with his parents in 1929. In 1946, he married the daughter of Rav Aharon Kotler. In 1962, he served as R”M in Yeshivas Chaim Berlin, then together with Rav Shmuel Kamenetsky, he founded the Philadelphia Yeshiva. In 1965, he opened Yeshivas Marom Tzion in Bayit Vegan, which evolved into Bais Hatalmud, now located in Sanhedria Hamurchevet. Rav Dov was a pivotal player in the teshuvah movement in Eretz Yisrael: the first yeshiva for baalei teshuvah, Shema Yisrael, was established in his yeshiva. It evolved into several other yeshivas.

Rav Dov Beirish Weidenfeld

Rav Dov Beirish (ben Yaakov) Weidenfeld, the Tchebiner Rav (1881-1965). His maternal grandfather was the seventh link in an unbroken chain of poskim beginning with the Shach. Beirishel's paternal grandfather was a disciple of R' Yaakov Loeberbaum, author of Nesivos HaMishpat. His father, Rav Yaakov Weidenfeld, founder of the Kochar MiYaakov Yeshiva, was his primary teacher until he was niftar in 1894, just two weeks prior to Reb Beirishel’s Bar Mitzvah. Thereafter, he became a student of his two older brothers, Rav Yitzchak of Horimlov (where Beirishel was also born) and Rav Nachum of Dombrova. At the age of 19, Rav Beirish married Rebbetzin Yachat, the daughter of Rav Yisrael Yosef Kluger of Tchebin. At the age of 24, he received semicha from Rav Yitzchak Shmelkish, the Beis Yitzchak. His wife administered a modest coal business to support him. In 1923, after 20 years of learning, he assumed the title of the Tchebiner Rav. Along with his wife and youngest daughter, the Rav was deported to Sverdelovsk, Siberia, in late 1940. With the dissolution of the labor camp, the Rav escaped to Buchara. The Tshebiner Rav arrived on the eve of Pesach, 1946, in Jerusalem, which he was to call home for the rest of his life, settling in the Shaarei Chessed neighborhood. His response were collected in the sefer Doveiv Meisharim. His son-in-law and successor as Rosh Yeshiva of Kochav MiYaakov was Rav Baruch Shimon Schneersohn.

Rav Raphael Aharon Ben-Shimon

In 1890, he recived an invitation to become the Rav of Cairo and take the title Chacham Bashi. He serve d in that capacity when the famous Cairo geniza was published, a collection of more than 200,000 Hebrew, Arabic, and Aramaic manuscripts found in the attic of of the Ibn Ezra Synagogue. Among his sefarim are Nahar Mitzrayim, Umitzur Devash, and Tuv Mitzrayim. He was buried in Har Hazeisim.

Rav Shimon Yehuda HaKohen Shkop

Rav Shimon Yehuda (ben Yitzchak Smuel) HaKohen Shkop of Grodno (1860-1939). Born in Turz, Poland, Rav Shimon studied in Mir at the age of 12, and then Volozhin at the age of 15, with Rabbi Chaim Soloveitchik. He was brought to Telshe in 1885 by his uncle, Rav Lazer Gordon. Rav Shimon’s brother-in-law, Rav Shlomo Zalman Abel, was one of the three founders of the Telshe Yeshiva. He taught at Telshe for 18 years. He succeeded Rav Alter Shmuelevicz as Rosh Yeshiva of Yeshiva Shaarei Torah in Grodno, from 1920 to 1939, transforming it into one of the finest yeshivos in Poland and beyond. In 1929, Rav Shimon Shkop came to America to raise funds for the yeshiva, and accepted R' Dov (Bernard) Revel's invitation to serve as Rosh Yeshiva of Yeshiva Rabbeinu Yitzchak Elchanan in New York. However, at the request of the Chofetz Chaim, Rav Shkop returned to Europe after six months. In 1939, the Soviet Red army marched into Grodno during the Asseres Yemei Teshuva. Most of the talmidim fled to Vilna, but Rav Shimon Shkop was too old and sick to travel and remained behind with a few talmidim. He passed away a month later. Rav Shimon Shkop was the author of Shaarei Yosher.

Rav Yosef Yehuda Leib Bloch 

Rav Yosef Yehuda Leib (ben Mordechai) Bloch (1860-1930). Born in Rusein, he succeeded his father-in-law, Rav Eliezer Gordon, as Rosh Yeshiva of the Telshe Yeshiva. Telz is one of the oldest towns in Lithuania, situated in the north-western part of Lithuania on the shores of Lake Mastis, and was already mentioned in the chronicles of a Crusader Order in 1320. Jews settled in Telz at the beginning of the 17th century. 2,500 people lived in Telz in 1797, of them 1,650 were Jews (66%). By 1870 Telz had 6,481 residents, including 4,399 Jews. Reb Yosef Leib already began studying under Reb Leizer at the age of 15, in Kelm and married Reb Leizer's daughter at the age of 21. Reb Yosef Leib initiated many innovations. In 1894, he attempted to introduce Mussar to the yeshiva's curriculum, and in 1897 he brought Rabbi Yehuda Leib Chasman zt"l to serve as the yeshiva's Mashgiach.

Rav Shalom (ben Yaakov) Weinberger, Tchaba Rav (1940-2014). The Rav led his kehillah on Rechov Yitzchok Blazer in the Bais Yisroel neighborhood of Yerushalayim and later in the Gush Shmonim neighborhood of Yerushalayim. He was buried in Har Hamenuchos.

Rav Yosef Ayeh Halperin

Rav Yosef Ayeh (ben Abba Aharon) Halperin (1953-2011). After learning in Ponevezh, he opened the Rosh Yosef Kollel in Yeshivas Shuvah Yisrael and delivered shiurim there; he appointed his brother as its Rosh Kollel. He authored Dvar Yom B’yomo and Midei Shabbos B’shabbato, both of which were translated into several languages.

Rav Alexander Zusha Friedman

Rav Alexander Zusha (ben Aharon Yehoshua) Friedman (1897-1943). In 1925, he was elected secretary of Agudas Yisrael, and a year leader he represented Agudah for the Board of Warsaw Jewish Community. He founded the Chorev Talmud Torah Network and was on the board of the Bais Yaakov of Cracow. He wrote a sefer called Kesef Tzaruf on the klalim of the Gemara “to help educate a generation which is not so knowledgable.” His magnus opus was Maayanah Shel Torah, in which he gathered the teaching of Gedolei Yisrael on the Torah. In the summer of 1942, his wife and 12 year old daughter – his only child, born after 13 years of marriage – were sent to Treblinka. He himself was taken to the Trawanki camp near Lublin in Adar 1943, and murdered there eight months later.

Rav Tzvi Hirsh Kalisher

Rav Tzvi Hirsh (ben Shlomo) Kalisher (1795-1874). Born in the town of Lissa in western Poland, he learned in the yeshiva of Rav Akiva Eiger in Posen and of the Chavas Daas in Lissa, settling in Tohran, his wife’s hometown. After a few years, he was appointed Rav of the city, a position he held for 40 years until his petira. Among his sefarim are Moznaim Lamishpat on Choshen Mishpat, Sefer Habris on Torah, Emunah Yesharah, Even Bochen, Drishas Tzion, and Pesach Hadaas. Rav Kalischer is best known today for his leading role in encouraging the resettlement of Eretz Yisrael and for his halachic views regarding the possibility of bring sacrifices in the absence of a Beis Hamikdash.  On the latter subject he corresponded with his teacher Rav Akiva Eiger and with the latter's son-in-law, the Chasam Sofer, who accepted some of his views. Regarding the settlement of Eretz Yisrael, Rav Kalischer taught that the Final Redemption will come about through "natural" means. Therefore he encouraged the establishment of organizations and groups to further the goal of resettling the Land.  Many rabbis opposed Rav Kalisher's efforts.

Rav Avraham Yosef Rice

Rav Avraham Yosef Rice (1802-1862). He was born in the village of Gochsheim, Bavaria. When he was one-and-a-half years old, a nurse carelessly let him fall from a table, and he became lamed for life. The accident may have been a blessing in disguise, for since his earliest childhood he devoted himself to intensive study of Torah. In 1840, he and his wife immigrated to the United States. After a brief attempt at reviving the Jewish community in Newport, Rhode Island, he accepted an appointment as the first rabbi of Congregation Nidche Israel in Baltimore. His fearless battles against assimilation and lax observance brought him into conflict with many of his congregants. In 1849, finding it impossible to resist the demand for reforms at Nidche Israel, he resigned his position, founded his own synagogue which was strictly orthodox; to support himself he opened a dry goods store, and then a grocery.

Rav Meshulam Zalman Chassid

Rav Meshulam Zalman Chassid of Frankfurt (1790).

Rav Moshe Birdogo

Rav Moshe (ben Avraham) Birdogo (1730). Rav Moshe resided in western Morocco and authored Rosh Mashbir.

Rav Aryeh Leib Gurwitz

Rav Aryeh Leib [Aryeh Zev] (“Reb Leib”) (ben Moshe Aharon) Gurwitz (Gurwicz) (1906-1982). He was born Leib Kushelevsky in the small town of Malat, Poland. After Leib had learned in the Mir for eight years, the Rosh Yeshiva, Rav Eliezer Yehuda Finkel, and the mashgiach ruchani, Rav Yeruchom Levovitz, recommended that he travel to study under the Brisker Rav. He later married the daughter of Rav Elya Lopian, and became Rosh Yeshiva of Gateshead. He authored Roshei She’arim (a compilation of some shiruim which he delivered in the yeshiva), Arza Devei Rav (which contains hundreds of chiddushim on Shas). His sefer Meorei She’arim was printed posthumously by his talmidim, and consists of mussar and hashkafic talks that Rav Gurwicz gave over the years.

Rav Kalonimus Kalman Shapira

Rav Kalonimus Kalman (or Kalmish) (ben Elimelech) Shapira, Piasetsna (Piacezna; Piaczetzna) Rebbe, author of Chovos Hatalmidim,  Aish Kodesh, and Tzav V'zeiruz (1889-1944). A direct descendant of the Magid of Kozhnitz and of the "Noam Elimelech" of Lizhensk, he was named after his maternal grandfather, the Maor Vashemesh. In 1905, Rav Kalonimus Kalman married Rachel Chaya Miriam, the daughter of Rav Yerachmiel Moshe of Kozhnitz. She helped him prepare his drashas and seforim, even adding pertinent insights of her own. After the Warsaw Ghetto uprising was crushed in Nissan 1943, Rav Klonimus Kalmish was taken to the Trevaniki (Travniki) work camp near Lublin. Prisoners who were completely "worked out" by exhaustion and starvation were removed and sent to the Treblinka and the Rebbe met his death there on 4 Cheshvan, 1944.

Rav Yaakov Yitzchak Dan Landa

Rav Yaakov Yitzchak Dan (ben Elimelech Menachem Mendel) Landa, the Strikover Rebbe (1943). He was murdered by the Nazis.

Rav Yoav Yehoshua Weingarten

Rav Yoav Yehoshua (ben Nassan Nota) Weingarten of Kintzk, the Chelkas Yoav (1845-1923). His foundation in learning was established by Rav Zev Nachum Borenstein, the Agudas Eizov, but his rav muvhak was his son, Rav Avraham Borenstein, the Avnei Nezer, who was only 6 years his elder. In 1883, Rav Yoav accepted the positions of Rav and Rosh Yeshiva in Litomirsk. In 1889, he became Rav of Gustinin, and founded a yeshiva there. From 1894 until his petira, he served as Rav in Kintzk. In 1894, he published Chlkas Yoav. He also published a sefer called Kava Dekesheisa, 103 unanswered kushyos on Shas intended to whet the minds of bnei yeshiva. After the petira of the Avnei Nezer, Rav Yoav accepted the authority of his son, the Shem MiShmuel. After his own petira, his only son, Rav Meir succeeded him as Rav of Kintzk. His son held the post for 27 years until he and his entire family were murdered. [3 Cheshvan, per Hamadia 2006]

Rav Yehuda Modern

Rav Yehuda Modern (1819-1893). Born in Pressburg (today Bratislava, Slovakia), Rav Yehuda Modern was among the most distinguished and respected Hungarian rabbis of the nineteenth century, despite the fact that he never held any rabbinic position.  Young Yehuda was a child prodigy, and by the age of eight was attending the Chasam Sofer's lectures.  As a teenager, his knowledge of the Gemara was so thorough that he could state how many times the name of Rava appeared on each page of Bava Basra. At the age of 18, Rav Modern set out for Ungvar (today Uzhgorod, Ukraine) to study in the yeshiva of Rav Meir Asch. Arriving there, and finding that Rav Asch was not at home, he decided to visit the Yismach Moshe in nearby Uhel (Satoraljaujhely, Hungary).  The Yismach Moshe was very impressed with the young scholar and proposed him as a match for Chaya Rachel, the daughter one of the leading citizens of Sighet.  Rav Yehuda and Chaya Rachel were married in 1837, and he lived the rest of his life in Sighet devoted entirely to Torah study and the performance of chessed. He declined all offers of rabbinic positions and all other honors. Rav Modern authored a Torah commentary, Pri Ha'etz, and a commentary on meseches Gittin entitled Zichron Shmuel in memory of his father-in-law. He was buried in the Kahana family ohel in Sighet, a structure that still exists today.

Rav Ovadia Yosef

Rav Ovadia (ben Yaakov) Yosef (1920-2013). Born in Iraq, he immigrated to Yerushalayim in 1924. As a teenager he studied at the Porat Yosef Yeshiva, where he learned under the rosh yeshiva, Rav Ezra Attiya. In 1949, after a brief stay in Cairo, Yosef studied at Bnei Zion, headed by Rav Tzvi Pesach Frank and also served on the Beis Din in Petah Tikva. In 1952, he published the first of what would be many sefarim, Chazon Ovadia on hilchos Pesach. Two years later he founded 'Or HaTorah' Yeshiva for gifted Sephardic Yeshiva students.Between 1953 and 1956, he published the first two volumes of his major work, Yabia Omer. Beginning in 1958, he served as Dayan in Yerushalayim. He was the Sephardi Chief Rabbi of Israel from 1973 to 1983.

Rav Don Ungarischer

Rav Don (ben Yerachmiel) Ungarischer, Rosh Yeshiva of Bais Medrash Elyon in Monsey for over 50 years (1923-2011). Born in Vienna, he served as the primary transmitter of the derech halimud of his father-in-law, Rav Reuven Grozovsky and his rebbi muvhak, Rav Shlomo Heiman. He helped publish Chidushei Rav Reuven and Chidushei Rav Shlomo.

Rav Shimon Groner

Rav Shimon Groner, Mashgiach, Yeshiva Rabbeinu Chaim Berlin (1932-2005). Born in Brownsville, NY, to Rabbi Schnayer Zalman and Fayga Rochel Groner. Reb Schnayer Zalman was born in Yerushalayim, a scion of the well-known Grossman family, and he was a talmid of Yeshivas Eitz Chaim. He passed away when Shimon was only fourteen. Reb Shimon went to Chaim Berlin, where the Rosh Yeshiva, Rav Yitzchak Hutner treated Shimon like a son. Rabbi Groner was married in 1959 to Nechama Dubba Fishbein and continued his learning in the Kollel Gur Aryeh of Chaim Berlin. He taught the seventh and ninth grades in Yeshiva Ohr Yisrael of Forest Hills and from there was called by Rav Hutner to help found the Mesivta Chaim Berlin in Flatbush. After four years, he became a maggid shiur in the beis medrash, and in 1978 was appointed mashgiach ruchni, a post he held for his remaining 27 years.

Rav Avraham Aba Zions 

Rav Avraham Aba Zions (1911-1995). Born in Brisk, Poland. His father passed away when Rav Aba was just nine-years-old. His mother would bring him to one of the talmidei chachomim in Brisk to have him tested every week. When Rav Aba was twelve-years-old, he was sent him to learn at the yeshiva of Rav Moshe Sokolovsky, author of the Imrei Moshe. Rav Aba was very close to the Imrei Moshe until the latter's petirah in 1931, and he assisted with the publishing of the Imrei Moshe's sefer on Maseches Beitza, "Meleches Yom Tov." After a few years, Rav Aba went to Kaminetz to learn by Rav Baruch Ber Lebowitz. In or about the year 1936, Rav Aba returned to Brisk, starting a Talmud Torah there. Shortly after the outbreak of the war, Rav Aba escaped to Vilna. He was instrumental in the printing of Rav Baruch Ber's sefer Birchas Shmuel. From there he joined the Mirrer Yeshiva bochurim as they traveled to Kobe, Japan, and eventually to Shanghai, China. After the war, Rav Aba came to New York and accepted a position as Rav of Congregation Knesses Israel in The Bronx, where he served for 28 years. In 1948, Rav Aba married Rivka Tellem, of Tavrig, Lithuania, whose family had settled in Newark.

Rav Mordechai Miller

Rav Mordechai Miller, principal of Gateshead Seminary (1920-2000); one of the closest students of  Rav Eliyahu Dessler. Rav Miller held a postgraduate degree in law. He had a promising future in the professional world. His uncle had a law firm in London and with his great talents he would have been given a good position. But he gave it all up in order to spend his life al haTorah ve'al ho'avodoh.

Rav Aryeh Zeev “Leib” Gurwicz

Rav Aryeh Zeev “Leib” (ben Moshe Aharon) Gurwicz (1906-1982), son-in-law of Rav Elyah Lopian and Rosh Yeshiva of Gateshead yeshiva Gedola. His brother was Rabbi Eliyahu (Elya) Kushelevksy (1910–1992), who later served as av beis din (head of the rabbinical court) of Bersheva. He moved to England in 1932.

Rav Yisrael Hager

Rav Yisrael (ben Moshe) Hager of Radowitz-America (1876-1942) – not be confused with Rav Yisrael Hager of Vizhnitz, the Ahavas Yisrael. He settled in America and founded Beis Midrash Bnei Yisrael and a yeshiva named Toras Chaim. He also worked hard to help support his father’s yeshiva in Tzefas and sponsored an orphanage there. Additionally, he helped publish his father’s sefer, Vayikach Moshe. He was buried in the Beth David Cemetary in Long Island.

Rav Yitzchak Zelig Morgenstern

Rav Yitzchak Zelig (ben Chaim Yisrael) Morgenstern, the Sokolover Rebbe (1864-1939). Born in Kotzk, he was the great - grandson of the Kotzker Rebbe. Married at the age of 18, he became Rav of Sokolov, a town near Shedlitz, at the age of 30. There he established the Yeshiva Beis Yisrael. In 1905, he succeeded his father as the Rebbe of Pilov. After a visit to Eretz Yisrael in 1924, he exhorted his followers to leave the Diaspora and settle the land. After the outbreak of World War II, he moved to Otwock, a village outside Warsaw. His eldest son, the Rabbi of Wengrov was stabbed to death by the Germans.

Rav Gedalia Yosef Bernstein

Rav Gedalia Yosef Bernstein (1908). Born in the city of Smilowitz, in Minsk (in modern-day Belarus), he arrived in the United States in 1890, settling in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. According to his matzeivah, he finished Shas every 3 years. He was buried in the Washington Cemtary.

Rav Yosef Zundel

Rav Yosef Zundel (ben Binyamin Beinish) of Salant (Lithuania) (1786-1865), teacher of R’ Yisrael Salanter; learned under Rav Chaim Volozhiner, then after his petira in 1821, he would make trips to learn with Rav Akiva Eiger. Rav Eliezer Horowitz

Rav Yisrael

Rav Yisrael (ben Shalom Shachna) of Ruzhin (1797-1850). Born to the Rebbe of Prohibisht (who was a son of Reb Avraham HaMalach, the son of the Maggid of Mezerich). He was engaged to the Rav of Berditchev at the age of seven; six years later, the chasuna took place. When Reb Yisrael turned sixteen his older brother, Reb Avraham (who had succeeded their father), was niftar, leaving no children. He was then succeeded by Reb Yisrael. When word reached the Rebbe that the Russian Czar intended to build a big church in the Old City of Yerushalayim, the Rebbe summoned Reb Nisan Bak who lived in Yerushalayim. Reb Nisan arrived there a few days ahead of the Russians and succeeded in buying the plot of land. The Czar was forced to buy a different plot of land, known today as the Russian Compound. The shul was known as the "Reb Nisan Bak Shul" and stood until 1948 when it was destroyed by the Arabs. Following the orders of the Czar, the Rebbe was locked up in the Kiev dungeons. The Rebbe spent 22 months locked in a small dark and damp cellar. A few days after the Rebbe was freed he fled Russia and settled in the town of Sadiger. The Rebbe's derech was carried on through his six sons. The Rebbe's oldest son, Reb Shalom Yosef, was niftar less than a year after his father and was succeeded by his son Reb Yitzchak, who became the first Bohusher Rebbe. The Ruzhiner's second son, Reb Avraham Yaakov, took his father's place in Sadiger. He had two sons, the eldest, Reb Yitzchak, was the first Boyaner Rebbe and the younger son, Reb Yisrael, was rebbe in Sadiger. The third son of the Ruzhiner was Reb Dov Ber who was rebbe in Lieov and the fourth son, Reb Menachem Nachum, was rebbe in Sthefanesht. The fifth son was Reb Dovid Moshe, the Chortkover Rebbe, and the sixth son was Reb Mordechai Shraga, the Husyatiner Rebbe. The Ruzhiner also had four daughters. The third daughter, Miriam, was married to Reb Menachem Mendel of Vishnitz, founder of the Vishnitzer dynasty.

Rav Yitzchak

Rav Elazar Simcha Wasserman 

Rav Elazar Simcha (ben Elchanan) Wasserman (1900-1992). The oldest son to his illustrious father, Rav Elchanan Wasserman, and a nephew of Rav Chaim Ozer Grodzensky, Rav Simcha learned at Novardok for several years, beginning shortly after his Bar Mitzvah, under the Alter of Novardok. He was also very close to the Chofetz Chaim. After his last visit with him, his father sent him to Strasbourg, France, where he started a yeshiva (at the time, the only yeshiva in France). He stayed until 1938, when he moved to America. He first taught at Torah Vodaas, where he became close to Rav Shraga Feivel Mendlowitz. He worked closely with Rav Aharon Kotler in the Vaad Hatzalah during WWII. In 1944, Rav Simcha established the Bais Yehuda Day School in Detroit, the first in Michigan, and appointed Rav Avraham Abba Freedman as a Rebbe. Their first Shavuos, they were the only two to learn all night in the Beis Midrash. When Rav Simcha left in 1953, he left Rav Avraham Abba, who stayed another 50 years.  He then founded  the West Coast Talmudic Seminary (WCTS), or Ohr Elchanan (named after his father) in Los Angeles. He asked Chabad to take over the building and school in 1977.  In 1979, he and his rebetzen (daughter of the Novardok rav, Rav Meir Abowitz) fulfilled a lifelong dream by moving to Eretz Yisrael. Together with Rav Moshe Chadash, he established Yeshiva Ohr Elchanan in Yerushalayim. Rav Simcha and his rebbetzin never had children. Yet, Rav Simcha was considered by many to be a leading authority on the subject of child-rearing.

Rav Baruch Hager

Rav Baruch (ben Yisrael) Hager, the Seret-Viznitz Rebbe, the Makor Baruch (1895-1963). He was named after his grandfather, the Imrei Baruch of Vizhnitz. He became Rav of Polein-Riskova, and then served as the Rav of Kotzman, Romania, for nine years. He established a Talmud Torah, a Bais Yaakov school and worked extensively for Agudas Yisrael. In 1935, Rav Baruch moved to Seret, a Romanian town of about 2,000 Jews. The Ahavas Yisrael passed away soon afterwards and Rav Baruch became the Admor of Seret-Vizhnitz. It is estimated that of about 150,000 Romanian Jews exiled to Transnistria (including all those from Seret), some 90,000 were murdered. Rav Baruch was ransomed for a huge sum in Adar of 1944 and made his way back to Romania. He finally moved to Antwerp, Belgium in 1946 together with his brother, the Imrei Chaim, and they stayed there for close to a year. He arrived in Eretz Yisrael in Sivan 1947, and set off to Haifa where he set up his court. There Rav Baruch established a yeshiva, a Talmud Torah and other Torah institutions. This laid the ground for the establishment of the famous community of Ramat Vizhnitz, built on the side of Haifa's Mount Carmel, laying its foundation stone on the 3rd day of Tammuz, 1954. However, he passed away before the culmination of his building project.

Shmuel Gaon

Rav Shmuel DiModina

Rabbi Shlomo Lorincz

Rabbi Shlomo Lorincz (1918-2009). served in the Knesset for Agudat Yisrael from 1951 until 1984, and a close confident of many gedolim. Born in Budapest, Lorincz made aliyah to Mandatory Palestine in 1939. He compiled memoirs of his discussions and experiences with the gedolim of the times in his book, B’Mechitzasam, later translated into English as "In Their Shadows."

Rav Yisrael Shapira

Rav Yisrael (ben Yehoshua) Shapira (Spira), the Bluzhover Rebbe (1890-1989). A grandson of the Bnei Yissoschar, Rav Tzvi Elimelech of Dinov. He is best known for being mechazek other Jews during the Holocaust. His divrei torah on the parashios and Yomim Tovim were published by his talmidim in the sefer Shufra D’Yisrael in 2007.

Rav Yosef Engel

Rav Yosef (ben Yehuda) Engel, Rav of Krakow and Vienna (1859-1919). Born in Austrian Poland, his rebbe refused to teach him any longer when he reached the age of 12, and between that age and his marriage at 19, he wrote eleven sefarim. Among his sefarim were Gilyonei Hashas, Shiv'im Panim LaTorah Lekach Tov, Esvan (or Asvin) D'Oraysa, and Beis HaOtzar, a Talmudic encyclopedia.  His only child, Miriam, married the heir to the leadership of the Kotzker chassidim, but he abdicated that position in order to remain near his father-in-law, Rav Yosef. At age 46, Rav Yosef left his wealthy father-in-law's home and, for the first time, had to seek a living.  He found a position as one of several rabbinical judges in Krakow. During World War I, Rav Yosef fled with hundreds of other Rabbis to Vienna, where he died.

Rav Avraham Dovid Wahrman

Rav Avraham Dovid Wahrman of Butchatch (1771-1840). Born in Nadvorna, Galicia (today, in the Ukraine). In addition to his father, Avraham Dovid also studied under his uncle Rav Yehoshua Charif. Rav Tzvi Hirsh Chayos

Rav Tzvi Hirsh (ben Meir) Chayos, the Maharatz Chayos (Chiyus), Rav of Zolkov (1805-1855). Born in Brody, he was a descendent of Rav Yitzchak Chiyus, the Zera Yitzchak. Rav Moshe Bornstein

Rav Moshe Bornstein (1914-2011). Born in Poltusk, Poland, he learned in the Novardok yeshiva. While there, he became very close to the Breslov leader, Rav Avraham Sternhartz. He moved to Eretz Yisrael in 1935, first settling in Haifa, then moving to Yerushalayim. He was taken hostage by Jordanians in 1948, along with eight other Brselover Chassidim; they were released after nine months in captivity.

Rav Akiva Glasner

Rav Akiva Glasner (1956). A descendant of the Chasam Sofer and of Rav Akiva Eiger, Rav Glasner succeeded his father, Rav Moshe Shmuel Glasner, as Chief Rabbi of Klausenberg, Rumania, in 1922, and served there until the deportation of the Jews in 1944. He was deported to Bergen-Belsen, but was saved from there on the famous "Kasztner train." (Rudolf Kasztner was a non-religious Hungarian Zionist who struck a deal with Adolf Eichman to save some 1,700 Jews in exchange for trucks. Years later, an Orthodox Israeli journalist accused Kasztner of acting improperly, and Kasztner sued for libel. After a celebrated trial, Kasztner lost. He was exonerated on appeal, but only posthumously, having been murdered in 1957. Among those saved by Kasztner was Rav Yoel Teitelbaum, the Satmar Rebbe) After the War, Rav Glasner lived in Zurich until his death at age 71. His works include: Dor Dorim and Ikvei Hatzon.

Rav Avraham Chaim Horowitz
